awd_titl_txt: An Adaptive System Identification Approach Using Mobile Sensors
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will benefit national interests by conducting research that provides a transformative approach to enable the identification of large dynamical systems with a small number of sensors. The results will be useful for applications like the damage diagnosis and performance assessment of bridges, pipelines, buildings, wind turbine towers, and other structures. In particular, the iterative approach to sensor placement will provide an unprecedented capability for system identification and localization of damage, feeding into a decision support framework to guide effective structural repair. This capability has the potential to speed current inspection processes for civil infrastructure and reduce costs by hundreds of millions of dollars annually. An integral part of this project is the inspiration and education of undergraduate and graduate students in the areas of system identification, feedback control, robotics, and structural engineering. This project will also reach K-12 students through Tufts' Student Teacher Outreach Mentorship Program. Participation of students from minorities is a priority and will be promoted by working directly with established programs at Tufts University.

Through this project a novel system identification framework will be developed, where identification is implemented using sequential data processing, and where mobile sensors are redeployed iteratively to enhance the accuracy of the identified system model. For system identification with mobile sensors, Bayesian inference-based identification and reinforcement learning techniques will be employed to find the future locations of sensors based on the feedback obtained from the current sensor placement. The methodology in this project will also include a path-planning component and a data-fusion component. The path-planning component balances modeling accuracy with energy and time constraints to determine the best candidate locations for data acquisition at each iterative step, while the data-fusion component will determine how to combine prior models with new data as efficiently as possible, considering resource constraints on communication and computation at the mobile sensors. The capabilities of the project's approach will finally be evaluated on a case study for the envisioned structural diagnosis application.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An iterative optimal sensor placement (OSP) framework was formulated for structural identification and model updating of structural systems using a small number of mobile sensors. Figure 1 shows the key steps in the proposed approach and an illustration of iterative deployment of mobile sensors.

The identification is formulated through a Bayesian model updating approach which is solved through asymptotic approximation for computational efficiency. In an iterative manner, the OSP is performed to minimize the information entropy in estimating the updating parameters of the model. Each OSP iteration is performed to find the next location of mobile sensors, where the prior probability distribution of updating parameters is assumed as the posterior probability distribution obtained from the previous iteration. This process is repeated until the uncertainties of updating parameters fall below a predetermined threshold. A forward sequential sensor placement algorithm is used to solve the OSP problem at each iteration. This algorithm provides a nearly-optimal solution and is much more efficient compared to an exhaustive search. This proposed framework is validated through a numerical case study, namely a model of the Dowling Hall Footbridge located at Tufts University campus. Updating parameters used in this study are considered as added mass at different segments of the bridge deck. The purpose of using added mass is to create a realistic pseudo damage on a specific portion of the bridge because added mass and loss of stiffness (common damage) have similar effects on vibration measurements. The proposed iterative system identification approach is evaluated for estimation of updating parameters considering different number of available sensors. Figure 2 shows the iterative implementation of the proposed approach on the Dowling Hall Footbridge for estimation of updating parameters (added mass at 5 segments of the footbridge deck).

This methodology decreases the number of sensors needed for accurate identification results which can reduce the cost of instrumentation. It is shown that the same number of sensors implemented iteratively provide better results than those implemented all at once (e.g., 3 iterations of 3 mobile sensors provide better results than 9 sensors at optimal locations in one iteration). Generally, OSP is prone to modeling errors since it is often performed at the instrumentation design phase and before having access to any data to mitigate modeling errors. However, the proposed iterative OSP overcomes this shortcoming by updating the model at each iteration using measurements and thus reducing the modeling errors. Therefore, another benefit of the proposed method over classic OSP is mitigating the modeling error gradually through sequential model updating at iterations of data collections.

We also developed optimization methods, that are the cornerstone of inference and reinforcement learning tasks, when the measurement data is geographically distributed. In such scenarios, natural to remote sensing and other applications with very large datasets, it may not be practically feasible to bring the entire data to a single computational device for learning and inference. Distributed methods rely on local device-level model training and inter-device communication for model aggregation. The algorithms that were developed as a part of this project use a novel combination of device-level variance reduction and network-level gradient tracking. In a series of papers, we have analyzed the convergence rate and performance of these algorithms and analytically shown that one such algorithm (GT-SARAH) achieves the optimal complexity for stochastic nonconvex optimization problems. We have further developed regimes where these algorithms outperform their centralized counterparts and further exhibit a communication-topology independent convergence behavior and performance.

This project also provided k-12 outreach in collaboration with Tufts Center for Engineering Education and Outreach (CEEO). The Outreach Learning Fellows (OLF) Program housed at the CEEO worked at local elementary and middle schools and different sites as part of engineering outreach to local communities. OLFs were trained to support young students in engineering education and social emotional learning. The fellows also participated in conversations about diversity, equity, inclusion, and justice as part of their weekly training meetings. CEEO also held a webinar for k-12 students and a series of professional development conversations with local teachers about engineering education and how to engage students. Special focus was given to how to involve students remotely during COVID.
